html: Parallelism of those who “fear” Jehovah and “heed” his servant suggests that one idea is synonymous with the other. Those who reject the servant, in other words, are those who don’t fear Jehovah. Jehovah sends his servant as a light to those who live in darkness and to open the eyes of the blind (Isaiah 42:6-7, 49:6,49:6#three_col">Isaiah 42:6-7, 16, 49:6-Isaiah 42:6-7, 16, 18-49:6; 49:6; 49:6#three_col">Isaiah 42:6-7, 49:6, 49:6#three_col">Isaiah 42:6-7, 16, 49:6-Isaiah 42:6-7, 16, 18-49:6; 49:6; 49:6-Isaiah 42:6-7, 16, 18-49:6; 49:6; 49:6, 49:6#three_col">Isaiah 42:6-7, 16, 49:6-Isaiah 42:6-7, 16, 18-49:6; 49:6; 49:6-Isaiah 42:6-7, 16, 18-49:6; 49:6; 49:6). As Jehovah’s voice to his people, he teaches them his law, the terms of his covenant (Isaiah 28:23; 42:4; 51:4-5; 55:4). Persons among them who “trust” in Jehovah and “rely” on him are also those who respond positively to his servant (Isaiah 11:10; 52:15; 55:5; 61:1-3).
